encryption.method: Advanced Encryption Standard with 128bit key in Counter with CBC-MAC mode with 8-Octet ICV (AES 128 CCM 8)
Advanced Encryption Standard with 128bit key in Counter with CBC-MAC mode (AES 128 CCM)
Advanced Encryption Standard with 128bit key in Galois/Counter mode (AES 128 GCM)

ChaCha stream cipher and Poly1305 authenticator (CHACHA20 POLY1305)

weakness: Export-grade cipher suite
These ciphers were designed for legal export in the 1990s but are now considered insecure due to their susceptibility to various attacks (e.g., brute-force attacks). Reference: NIST SP 800-57.
Non-ephemeral Key Exchange
This key exchange method does not provide Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS), meaning that if the private key is compromised, all past communications can be decrypted by an attacker. Reference: RFC 5246.
Raccoon Attack
This is a type of Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attack where hackers can intercept and alter communications during the key exchange process, particularly when using DHE key exchange. Reference: RFC 3526.
Anonymous key exchange
This method obscures the identities of the communicating parties, reducing security and making it easier to execute MitM attacks. Reference: RFC 4346.

encryption.method: Data Encryption Standard with 40bit key in Cipher Block Chaining mode (DES40 CBC)
weakness: Cipher Block Chaining
In certain implementations, using the CBC mode with DES has known vulnerabilities that attackers can exploit. Reference: NIST SP 800-67.
Data Encryption Standard
DES uses a 56-bit key, which is no longer secure due to advancements in computational power. Reference: NIST FIPS PUB 46-3.
Secure Hash Algorithm 1
SHA-1 has been shown to be vulnerable to collision attacks, allowing two different inputs to produce the same hash value. Reference: NIST SP 800-107.
Export-grade cipher suite

Export-grade cipher suite
These ciphers were designed for legal export in the 1990s but are now considered insecure due to their susceptibility to various attacks (e.g., brute-force attacks). Reference: NIST SP 800-57.
Non-ephemeral Key Exchange
This key exchange method does not provide Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS), meaning that if the private key is compromised, all past communications can be decrypted by an attacker. Reference: RFC 5246.
Cipher Block Chaining
In certain implementations, using the CBC mode with DES has known vulnerabilities that attackers can exploit. Reference: NIST SP 800-67.
Data Encryption Standard
DES uses a 56-bit key, which is no longer secure due to advancements in computational power. Reference: NIST FIPS PUB 46-3.
Message Digest 5
The MD5 algorithm has known collision vulnerabilities, enabling attackers to forge data. Reference: RFC 1321.
